Package nl.naturalis.yokete.view

Interface ViewData

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractViewData, BeanViewData, MapViewData, PathViewData
    public interface ViewData
    A generic interface for objects that mediate between the data layer and view layer. ViewData objects serve two purposes:
    1. To provide name-based access to the model beans (or whatever else) served up by the data layer. A RenderSession takes the names found in a Template and asks the client-provided ViewData object to come up with a value for them.
    2. To stringify the values served up by the data layer so they can be "inserted" into the blanks of the template. Note that this does not entail escaping of any kind (e.g. HTML escaping). That is taken care of separately.

    You can write your own ViewData implementations or use one of three implementations in the nl.naturalis.yokete.view.data package.

    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      Optional<List<ViewData>> getNestedViewData​(Template parent, String childTemplateName)
      Returns a ViewData object containing the values for the specified nested template.
      Optional<List<String>> getValue​(Template template, String varName)
      Returns the value of the specified template variable.

    • Method Detail

      • getValue

        Optional<List<String>> getValue​(Template template,
                                String varName)
                         throws RenderException
        Returns the value of the specified template variable. Implementations must distinguish between true null values and the variable not being present in the source data at all. In the latter case they must return an empty Optional. If the value served up by the data layer is null, you can either decide to still return an empty Optional, or stringify the null value to a non-null String. If the Renderer receives an empty Optional, it will assume that you don't want to set the variable just yet. (In the end, of course, all variables must have been substituted with actual values.)

        The value of the variable comes in the form of a List of strings. If the list contains more than one string, all strings are inserted adjacently at the location of the variable. This can be useful if the variable represents not a simple, scalar value value but an HTML snippet. For example, if you have this template: 

          <html>
    <body>
      <table>
        ~%rows%
      </table>
    </body>
  </html>

        Then the @code ViewData} object could supply this value for the rows variable: 

         List.of("<tr><td>ONE</td></tr>",
  "<tr><td>TWO</td></tr>",
  "<tr><td>THREE</td></tr>")

        If the List is empty, the Renderer will replace the variable with an empty string. This allows for conditional rendering. By supplying the Renderer with an empty List, you effectively tell the Renderer to suppress rendering the variable. Note that this is probably more useful when rendering nested templates.

        The template argument is the Template containing the variable. Implementations could use it for pre-caching or other purposes, but are free to ignore it.

        Parameters:
        template - The Template that contains the variable
        varName - The name of the template variable
        Returns:
        An Optional containing the stringified version of the variable's value or an empty Optional
        Throws:
        RenderException

      • getNestedViewData

        Optional<List<ViewData>> getNestedViewData​(Template parent,
                                           String childTemplateName)
                                    throws RenderException
        Returns a ViewData object containing the values for the specified nested template. See getValue for the precise contract for this method
        Parameters:
        parent - The Template that contains the specified nested template
        childTemplateName - The name of the nested template
        Returns:
        An Optional containing a nested ViewData object
        Throws:
        RenderException
